conclusion: Consider the motion of the conductor rod OC and the generation of induced electromotive force (emf) in the frame.
The rod OC is rotating with angular velocity œâ.
The area swept by the rod OC in a time dt is given by the change in the angle Œ∏, which is dŒ∏ = œâ dt.
The radius of the semi-circular frame is r, so the instantaneous length of OC is r sin(Œ∏).
The magnetic flux Œ¶ through the area swept by OC is Œ¶ = B ‚ãÖ A, where A is the area of the sector swept by OC.
The area A of the sector is 1/2 r^2 Œ∏.
The rate of change of flux (induced emf) is given by ùìî = -dŒ¶/dt = -d/dt (B ‚ãÖ 1/2 r^2 Œ∏).
Since Œ∏ = œâ t, we have ùìî = B ‚ãÖ 1/2 r^2 œâ.
The current I induced in the circuit is given by Ohm's Law: I = ùìî/R = (B ‚ãÖ 1/2 r^2 œâ)/R.
The power P delivered by the external force is the product of the induced current and the voltage across the resistor: P = I^2 R.
Substituting the value of I, we get P = ((B ‚ãÖ 1/2 r^2 œâ)/R)^2 R.
The power of the external force doing work is P = B^2 r^4 œâ^2 / 4R.
